target_title: Tab thumbnails have no drag style

note.body:
I would recommend referencing iOS' animation system as it is elegant and differentiates between taps, drags, and long presses quite well.

When something is briefly tapped, the action just happens with a frame of highlighting before triggering the action to give a visual cue to the user. When long pressing, there is a delay period where the element slowly scales up until popping in to the final size of the drag/long press. If, during the animation, you start to drag, it will initiate a drag and usually add a pronounced shading effect below the element and scale it ever so slightly to show how it is literally raised or "picked up". Releasing will smoothly animate it scaling down to the original size. Nearly all actions on iOS are uninterruptible, too, which is very nice and feels natural. A good example of this is the "long press" action. Even *after* the long press is initiated, the action can be canceled by starting to drag. This is extremely important when we're talking about users with motor skill impairment as they may struggle to drag the item before the right click is engaged so it is important that we can allow slower users to accomplish their goals. You also only need to briefly press before dragging to activate it, though there is a healthy distance threshold to account for different levels of motor coordination such as parkinsons.

The way they animate the actions is of particular interest. There is a slow buildup and then, near the peak of the animation, it suddenly "pops" to visually indicate the triggering of an action. Also, when trying to drag something, it sort of interpolates the translation of the element between its anchor and the finger. This way, it feels like the element is "stuck" in its original place and you need to pull it out of place to move it, as though there's a dab of glue or a magnet holding it in place.

I'm not saying you need to imitate this system exactly. Just that it is very intuitive and elegant and I, as a user, appreciate the ease of use and fluidity of the system. It is worth taking inspiration from as it offers a really natural-feeling experience when it comes to cases like this and makes it accessible to users from all walks of life and should be in line with GNOME's HIG. iOS feels very natural to use and not very rigid and programmatic like how most desktop software feels to use on a touchscreen and we should learn from it.

Here's a demo (Encoded in HEVC/H.265):

![ScreenRecording_12-29-2024_17-31-17_1](/uploads/8d4db1eccc6a6edb1f997f0eeebc9fb1/ScreenRecording_12-29-2024_17-31-17_1.mp4)

note.body: Ideally the sidebar should always be at an OK width. Requiring people to constantly change its size manually to be able to use the app smoothly, is what we jokingly refer to as [shit work](https://zachholman.com/posts/shit-work/). If we add this to libadwaita, I'm concerned about developers enabling it on "auto-pilot" once requested to do so instead of actually trying to solve the underlying issue (which is likely to be awkward width thresholds, something that should be fixed [for everyone by default](https://ometer.com/preferences.html)).

note.body:
> as some code paths failed to account for the case of having no children.

If you're wondering, [`nat -= child_spacing;`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libadwaita/-/blob/main/src/adw-wrap-layout.c#L521) was being done whether there were any children or not, and [`line_spacing * (n_lines - 1)`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libadwaita/-/blob/main/src/adw-wrap-layout.c#L564) was being added without checking for it either. But instead of adding checks around those, I opted to just handle the no-visible-children case explicitly.

note.body: Note that `inverse_lerp` here is different from `inverse_lerp` in `AdwClampLayout`: given `adw_lerp (a, b, t) -> r`, the one in `AdwClampLayout` does `t = inverse_lerp (a, b, r)` (we know both of the bounds and want to find progress), and the one here does `b = inverse_lerp (a, r, t)` (we know progress and one of the bounds, want to find the other). It's also a lot less numerically stable.

note.body:
Sorry for the wall of text.

> What's wrong with notifying when the visible page is null?

Nothing - in fact, I think it's expected behavior that it still should.  My initial solution to set `old_visible_page` to `NULL` caused it to skip notifying, which was wrong.

> Like you mentioned a crash in builder, what's the backtrace?

I can get you the full backtrace if you want but here's the relevant stuff.  Everything above this is routing the close button event to here.
```
Program terminated with signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
#0  0x00007fb16ac95c6a in ADW_IS_NAVIGATION_PAGE (ptr=0x55bc4ee1d590) at ../src/adw-navigation-view.h:24
24	G_DECLARE_DERIVABLE_TYPE (AdwNavigationPage, adw_navigation_page, ADW, NAVIGATION_PAGE, GtkWidget)
[Current thread is 1 (Thread 0x7fb15b1f7e40 (LWP 2))]
(gdb) bt full
#0  0x00007fb16ac95c6a in ADW_IS_NAVIGATION_PAGE (ptr=0x55bc4ee1d590) at ../src/adw-navigation-view.h:24
        __inst = 0x55bc4ee1d590
        __t = Python Exception <class 'TypeError'>: can only concatenate str (not "NoneType") to str
        __r = <optimized out>
#1  adw_navigation_page_get_tag (self=0x55bc4ee1d590) at ../src/adw-navigation-view.c:2243
        _g_boolean_var_22 = <optimized out>
        priv = <optimized out>
        __func__ = "adw_navigation_page_get_tag"
#2  0x00007fb16ac989f4 in adw_navigation_view_replace (self=0x55bc4faed050, pages=0x0, n_pages=0) at ../src/adw-navigation-view.c:2912
        visible_page = <optimized out>
        old_visible_page = 0x55bc4ee1d590
        added_pages = 0x55bc4fb5e0c0
        i = <optimized out>
        old_length = 1
        visible_page = <optimized out>
        old_visible_page = <optimized out>

        _g_boolean_var_55 = <optimized out>
        _g_boolean_var_56 = <optimized out>
        c = <optimized out>

        length = <optimized out>
#3  adw_navigation_view_replace (self=0x55bc4faed050, pages=pages@entry=0x0, n_pages=n_pages@entry=0) at ../src/adw-navigation-view.c:2835
        visible_page = <optimized out>
        old_visible_page = <optimized out>
        added_pages = <optimized out>
        i = <optimized out>
        old_length = <optimized out>
        __func__ = "adw_navigation_view_replace"
        c = <optimized out>
        new_visible_page = <optimized out>
        length = <optimized out>
#4  0x000055bc0cdfe6de in ide_tweaks_window_clear (self=self@entry=0x55bc4fb38d60) at ../src/libide/tweaks/ide-tweaks-window.c:145
        __func__ = "ide_tweaks_window_clear"
#5  0x000055bc0cdfe793 in ide_tweaks_window_dispose (object=0x55bc4fb38d60) at ../src/libide/tweaks/ide-tweaks-window.c:284
        self = 0x55bc4fb38d60
        __func__ = "ide_tweaks_window_dispose"
#6  0x00007fb16c462f34 in g_object_unref (_object=0x55bc4fb38d60) at ../gobject/gobject.c:4415
```
and
```
(gdb) p *__inst
$1 = {g_class = <error reading variable: Cannot access memory at address 0xaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa>}
```
The real issue is that it's trying to access freed memory in `ADW_IS_NAVIGATION_PAGE (old_visible_page)`.  Here's the macro expanded:
```
static inline gboolean ADW_IS_NAVIGATION_PAGE(gpointer ptr) {
    return ((( {
        GTypeInstance *__inst = (GTypeInstance *) (ptr);
        GType __t = (adw_navigation_page_get_type());
        gboolean __r;
        if (!__inst) __r = (0);
        else if (__inst->g_class && __inst->g_class->g_type == __t) __r = (!(0));
        else __r = g_type_check_instance_is_a(__inst, __t);
        __r;
    })));
}
```
When it executes `__inst->g_class` it tries to read from `0xaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa` (i.e. `MALLOC_PERTURB_`).  I admit I'm not very familiar with gobject so I might be missing something here. 

> What's the higher level bug you're fixing?

Crash when closing the Builder Preferences window.

> Is it doing something in the signal handler that crashes?

I don't believe so.

note.body:
> Wait, but if the problem is with `old_visible_page`, why are you checking the new one?

The code doesn't make that clear, sorry.  The reason is because `adw_navigation_view_get_visible_page(self)` returns `NULL` if the `navigation_stack` length is 0, i.e., all pages have been removed.  There's a couple different ways to solve this though, so if you have a preferred way, please feel free to just close this MR and merge your fix.  I don't really care about the credit :)

You could also check whether `g_hash_table_contains (added_pages, old_visible_page)`.  Originally, I set `old_visible_page` to NULL if it was removed earlier (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libadwaita/-/merge_requests/1332/diffs?diff_id=1270487&start_sha=487d91b40b2e0219115ef8bbadcf8f6ff74f0a38) to fix the issue, but that caused the notify test to fail.

target_title: overlay-split-view: Add sidebar resizing via drag gestures

note.body:
Hmm, ok. I'm being convinced. I think that would work for most things.  

I do have a design question for you, though.  I realize I'm going off on a bit of a tangent so let me know if I should switch to matrix.  I also went through the gnome HIG docs in case they answered my question before I bugged you again, but couldn't find a definite answer.

Here it is.  Wall of text, sorry!

Would you also recommend non-resizable sidebars for a complex app like Builder? In Builder, a single utility pane has multiple tabs/views that can each hold potentially very different size requirements, like a terminal / documentation / file tree / debugger / diagrams / diff viewer / etc., and those views can change based on the currently displayed content.

You could probably set a sane default size that would cover most use cases (and use line wraps/ellipses for text, etc), but I imagine that you would run into edge cases fairly frequently where the text/widgets needed to be scrolled or expanded to find or look at something, but you wanted to keep the current text/widgets on screen as well.

I suppose you could get around some of those edge cases with clever/good design, but it would probably be pretty frustrating to run into...

OK. might be nice to have in libpanel docs as an alternative solution to reduce dependencies on libpanel if all they want is a resizable sidebar.

Since resizable sidebars are not encouraged, is there any encouraged solution for issues like this where the sidebar will hide relevant info/widgets (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/-/issues/3010), or for Builder's sidebar requirements?

They seem to be leaning towards middle-ellipsizing (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/-/merge_requests/1472), but that would only work for text and that MR has been in limbo for 7mos.

Maybe auto-resizing the sidebar to fit its children? Or expanding it on mouse hover? Or is there no decided way to deal with that yet and this is a design team question?

And finally - GtkPaned still exists and can be used. Yeah, it's not adaptive, but we have AdwMultiLayoutView, so it's really easy to change it into sth else - even a collapsed split view - on mobile.

It also doesn't have the split view styles, but it's not very hard to style it that way.

target_title: overlay-split-view: Add sidebar resizing via drag gestures

note.body:
Thing is - resizing can be done on the app side. Make a widget that has a resizable handle on one side and reports its preferred width as a minimum width in measure(). Set it as the sidebar. Then disable automatic sizing in AdwOverlaySplitView - min width 0, max width 9999999, fraction 0.

I don't want this in libadwaita because it's a lot of fragile code to maintain, and we generally discourage resizable sidebars in the first place.

The icon palette is a good example of this *way more general* concept in color theory. But I could show you numerous paintings and designs too.

> And here the light greys lean blue.

And yes, they do, but more so as they get darker\* (at least eyeballing it, HEX is hard).

Like the rule here isn't light = yellow, dark = blue, it's just dark = more blue. Wherever the baseline is is arbitrary, and here it looks better with a colder one.

\* besides fg because while that's really dark by default, it's used with lower opacities a lot, and so to keep it more neutral across the board.

> Someone who can see this difference will later open a bug asking why the colors look wrong, what do I say then?

I don't think they will. The colors still work as they did before, they don't clash. target_title: stylesheet: Slightly tint grays to make them colder

note.body:
Because a lot of widgets' backgrounds are mixed from fg, it doesn't look consistent without that. Like if you have something with 50% opacity, the blue will only be there half as much as it is in the background, which is not enough for the shades to look consistent.

It is still a pretty unopinionated grey that will work on any background where it makes sense wrt brightness. The point of it is to be more natural.

Think of it another way: if you changed the color of the orange bg by as much as the fg changed in the other direction (so making it more warm), while retaining the original color blend of the fg with opacity, you would not think it's clashing either. Apps would not be expected to override these tiny changes if they change bg because it still looks neutral.

The fact that you can't easily see the difference is a feature, not a bug :)
This is just a common trick in UI in general, nothing special that we're doing.

Mm, many problems here.

1. why is this here and not in GTK? Yes, the tiled issue was here, but GTK already provides a tiled state, so we can know when it's tiled. We don't have a way to know someone is running a weird hack.

3. Everywhere else, .solid-csd (the fallback for non-composited X11) doesn't have shadows either

Either way, this is not really actionable so I'm gonna close it.

note.body:
> The light mode high-contrast seems fine to me overall, […]

Something just came back to my mind when thinking about the light style, in the case of libadwaita, there _is_ one thing I find to be dearly missing from it when running high-contrast mode: having borders around buttons: https://gitlab.gnome.org/Teams/Design/whiteboards/-/issues/126

That it wouldn't be handled by high-contrast mode is a bit disappointing to me as it reduces the value proposition of HC mode for me and my family members, as it seemed like the only potential way to offset the problems seen in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libadwaita/-/issues/228 / https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libadwaita/-/issues/301 ; however my understanding from !502 is that it was determined that it should be a separate thing (a standalone setting?) instead of controlled by high-contrast mode, and that if a MR is proposed to implement that part separately from HC, it would not necessarily be rejected outright…

target_title: Some widgets use low contrast background when high contrast mode is enabled

note.body:
One thing in particular that I would like to suggest here is focusing on the **dark mode version of high contrast.**

The light mode high-contrast seems fine to me overall, but dark mode is where I feel the accessibility gains might be most significant, because using "pure black" (or at least darker shades of gray) in the "combined dark + high-contrast" context would probably make the UIs much more usable for those with some types of light sensitivity, as the still bright greys can overall be debilitating to them (increased strain, headaches, etc.).

target_title: libadwaita 2.0 Tracking Issue

note.body:
We currently have a fallback style for header bars inside `GtkBox` and such, and an override that changes it to a shadow for `GtkWindow:titlebar` and toolbar views with raised style.

![image](/uploads/00bcaeda59c9f425b7a48263802941ef/image.png)

It's there for technical reasons, as a shadow would end up behind content - apps should not be using boxes for this, but some still do.

If we have an API break, I'd like to remove that and just use a shadow. If someone is still using a box for header bars, it's their problem at this point, they shouldn't be doing that in the first place.

Note: this style is actually different from top-bar-style=raised-border. That border overlaps the content just like the shadow, while this one is next to the content:

![image](/uploads/fae29f86c527362c6b1f97be90cfe0ff/image.png)

![image](/uploads/a7e2cb0f73d03a8b9db0fcebcca39fab/image.png)

Yes, we have 2 different border styles. :upside_down:

target_title: Transparency Impacting Legibility

note.body:
Yeah, I don't think that works. Even if it had a shadow instead of a border, that's just not distinct enough. Right now it's black so stands out a lot more (as long as the background is not black, anyway)

Another 3 things:

1. GTK touch text selection menu uses OSD and will not be affected by deprecation, so that one is gonna remain bad, unless we tweak osd popovers everywhere (which we probably should)

2. Fullscreen header bars frequently use osd-like styling. Granted, the entirety of fullscreen needs to be rethought, but it's still a place people commonly use .osd or osd-like styles for.

3. The entirety of camera styles.

https://gitlab.gnome.org/Teams/Design/app-mockups/-/raw/master/camera/camera-next.png

Esp toggle groups here are _very_ involved and I absolutely don't want apps carrying those styles - it's extremely easy to mess up e.g. focus ring on the selected toggle.

So while the current .osd is a mess, I think it would make sense to have _something_ in libadwaita, just because these styles are not simple (tho they are _considerably_ simpler now that variables exist)

note.body:
**4. Make toasts opaque**

On the design side we agree that going opaque for toasts is the best path forward. The main open question we have is what style they should have. There is a concern that, if we follow the app's UI style the toasts may become hard to identify, particularly in dark style:

![Screenshot_from_2024-10-03_09-39-54](/uploads/18096f215c0ce27d8e31630e78270024/Screenshot_from_2024-10-03_09-39-54.png)

Suggestions for how to handle this would be welcome.

target_title: Transparency Impacting Legibility

note.body:
This was discussed on a design call this week, I think this issue can be spun off into separate things to address, which might help to tackle the parallel topics that have been ongoing in this thread.

**1. Make small overlay elements opaque and follow theme.**

Standalone floating overlay controls and the touch editing popover are clear candidates for going opaque and following the application theme, including High Contrast--in other words dropping `.osd`. This should cover the cases like Maps, Papers, Loupe, etc. where there's a handful of controls overlaying the content.

**2. Treat media/content applications as special cases**

Rich content apps will usually have large surfaces that cover content--like in Showtime--where transparency can still be considered/used for both the container for controls and secondary elements, but this would be a style local to the app and tackled case-by-case.

**3. Figure out treatment for groups of overlay buttons**

What to do with groups of buttons in the overlay is still an open question--mainly whether to group or not to group--and what the style of the group will be.

***

~~Backdrop blur still a wishlist item but that'll have to be tackled in GTK~~

target_title: Transparency Impacting Legibility

note.body:
I would also like to address this in 48.

In keeping with the original issue, I'm still going to hold fast to the idea that the overlay style of some elements should be fully opaque (given we don't have backdrop blur) if it is appearing over UI elements to mitigate the bleed-through of text, icons, and borders that impact their usability.

I would be satisfied if the use of transparency in the touch editing controls and toast style were revisited/removed to fix that issue. I think rich content applications--video, images, maps (yes), documents--could be approached case by case or be given a special class.

***

I would be in favour of deprecating `.osd` (because it's misused and too generic) and bringing some clarity to the style here and where they should be used. A reasonable direction to me would be to have a style class for when elements are over rich content, where transparency might be a valid option.

I have no opposition to light style controls and agree all of these things should also be non-transparent regardless in high contrast mode.
